questions.text: Otoconia are concerned with function of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The macula is the sensory end organ of the utricle and saccule, whose function is linear balance, that is associated with that of the linear acceleration.

Utricle and Saccule:

  • The utricle lies in the posterior part of the bony vestibule. It receives the five openings of the three semicircular ducts.
  • It is also connected to the saccule through the utricular saccular duct. The sensory epithelium of the utricle is called the macula and is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration.
  • The saccule also lies in the bony vestibule, anterior to the utricle and opposite the stapes footplate. Its sensory epithelium is also called the macula. Its exact function is not known. It probably also responds to linear acceleration and deceleration.
  • In Ménière's disease, the distended saccule lies against the stapes footplate and can be surgically decompressed by perforating the footplate.
  • Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of the macula.
  • BPPV( Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) occurs due to displaced otoconia from the macula.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Oculovestibular reflex (Option A): Involves integration of eye movement reflexes with vestibular inputs-more complex and not specifically just otoconia.

Rotatory nystagmus (Option B): A response to angular acceleration detected by semicircular canals, not otoconia.

Angular acceleration (Option D): Detected by semicircular canals, not otoconia.

questions.text: All of the following are true about anatomy of the ear except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The aqueduct of the cochlea connects the perilymphatic space of the inner ear to the subarachnoid space of the brain.
  • It is the Vestibular Aqueduct that connects the endolymph to the endolymphatic sac.

Inner Ear fluids and their circulation:

  • There are two main fluids in the inner ear: perilymph and endolymph.

Perilymph:

  • It resembles extracellular fluid and is rich in Na ions. It fills the space between the bony and the membranous labyrinth.
  • It communicates with CSF through the aqueduct of cochlea, which opens into the scala tympani near the round window.
  • This duct is not a direct communication but contains connective tissue resembling arachnoid through which perilymph percolates.
  • There are two views regarding the formation of perilymph: (i) It is a filtrate of blood serum and is formed by capillaries of the spiral ligament, and (ii) it is a direct continuation of CSF and reaches the labyrinth via the aqueduct of the cochlea.

Endolymph:

  • It fills the entire membranous labyrinth and resembles intracellular fluid, being rich in K ions.
  • It is secreted by the secretory cells of the stria vascularis of the cochlea and by the dark cells (present in the utricle and also near the ampullated ends of semicircular ducts).
  • There are two views regarding its flow: (i) longitudinal, i.e., endolymph from the cochlea reaches saccule, utricle and endolymphatic duct and gets absorbed through the endolymphatic sac, which lies in the subdural space and (ii) radial, i.e. endolymph is secreted by the stria vascularis and also gets absorbed by the stria vascularis.
  • This view presumes that the endolymphatic sac is a vestigial structure in man and plays no part in endolymph absorption.

questions.text: Ductus Reuniens connects which two structures of the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Cochlear duct is connected to the saccule by the ductus reuniens.

Cochlear Duct:

  • Also called the membranous cochlea or the scala media. It is a blind, coiled tube.

It appears triangular on cross-section, and its three walls form the :

  • The basilar membrane, which supports the organ of Corti.
  • The Reissner's membrane, which separates it from the scala vestibuli.
  • The stria vascularis, which contains vascular epithelium and is concerned with the secretion of endolymph.

questions.text: What is Cupula in inner ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cupula is the gelatinous layer around Crista (the sensory end organ of the semicircular canals). Cristae are concerned with angular acceleration.
  • The macula is the sensory end organ of the utricle and saccule. It has otoconia or otoliths, which are calcium carbonate crystals in the gelatinous layer of the macula. They are concerned with the function of linear balance.

Cupula:

  • It functions like a fluid valve, creating a barrier that allows endolymph movement to deflect it under head rotation.
  • Endolymph fluid within the semicircular canal lags due to inertia. This creates pressure on the cupula, deflecting it in the opposite direction.
  • The embedded hair cell bundles are bent, resulting in either depolarisation or hyperpolarisation.
  • A neural signal is sent via the vestibular nerve, informing the brain of this angular acceleration.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

questions.text: : As per the travelling wave theory of hearing given by Von Bekesy, sound energy creates a wave-like movement in which structure of the inner ear.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Travelling wave theory of hearing has been given by Von Bekesy, which states that - A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude at a particular place in the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment.
  • Therefore, higher frequencies are sensed in the basal turn, and lower frequencies are sensed in the apex of the cochlea.

questions.text: When the head moves to the right slowly, what changes in the ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Three semicircular canals lie at right angles to each other. The canal, which lies at right angles to the axis of rotation, is stimulated the most. So the horizontal canal will respond maximally to rotation on the vertical axis(i.e movement of head to right or left) and so on.
  • The endolymph fluid inside these canals has inertia, so it lags behind the motion of the canal itself.
  • As the head turns right, the endolymph lags, effectively flowing 'leftward' relative to the skull.
  • That means in the right horizontal canal, the fluid flows away from the ampulla, while in the left horizontal canal, it flows toward the ampulla.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fitzgerald Bithermal Caloric Test: This is a Test for the lateral Semicircular Canal (aka Horizontal SCC)

Steps-

  • Patient is lying supine with the head lifted 30° (This brings lateral SCC in a vertical plane).
  • EAC is irrigated with Warm (44°C) and Cold (30°C) water.
  • This will produce nystagmus (Note the latency, duration, (direction) in all normal people.
  • With cold water stimulation, the eyes move towards the opposite side.
  • With warm water stimulation, the eyes move towards the side.

questions.text: plot shown in the picture is used for which investigation in ENT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is Claussen's Butterfly Chart. It is used to plot the findings of ENG caloric testing.

Method of using the above chart:

Caloric test setup -The patient lies supine with a 30° head tilt to align the horizontal canal vertically. Each ear is irrigated with warm (≈44���°C) and cold (≈30���°C) water while measuring the maximum slow-phase nystagmus beats in 30 seconds.

Plotting results -Each irrigation yields a beat frequency. These are assigned codes:

  • 0=normal,
  • 1=hypoactive (below normal),
  • 2=hyperactive (above normal)

Butterfly quadrants-Four quadrants correspond to:

  • Right warm, Right cold, Left warm, Left cold.
  • The coded results form a 'butterfly' pattern when graphed

Interpretation:

  • 000 -All quadrants normal - intact bilateral vestibular function.
  • 1100-Right ear weak response (canal paresis) - right peripheral lesion.
  • 0011-Left ear weak - left peripheral lesion.
  • 2222 -Bilateral hyperactivity - possible brainstem or cerebellar involvement.
  • 1001/0110- Central (brainstem) signs with directional preponderance

Explanation of other options:

Tympanometry(Option A): produces a single���peak compliance vs pressure curve (tympanogram), not a butterfly plot.

Audiometry(Option B): uses audiograms that plot hearing threshold vs frequency, not this shape.

Brainstem evoked response audiometry (Option C): yields waveforms over time (0-10 ms) with labelled peaks (Waves I-V), again, nothing like this pattern.

Epley's manoeuvre is used in the treatment of BPPV(Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo). The remaining tests are of vestibular function.

questions.text: The given investigation in the picture checks the function of which structure of the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given picture shows cVEMP(Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential).
  • In VEMP, we stimulate the saccule with sound, and we record the contractions of the Sternocleidomastoid muscle(Vestibulocollic reflex).
  • This test checks the inferior vestibular division of the 8thnerve, as the saccule is supplied by this nerve.

Types of VEMP:

cVEMP (cervical VEMP):

  • Stimulates the saccule and its pathway via the inferior vestibular nerve.
  • Recorded from the contracted sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle in the neck.

oVEMP (ocular VEMP):

  • Stimulates the utricle and its pathway via the superior vestibular nerve.
  • Measured via extraocular muscle responses (e.g., under the eye)

questions.text: All are true about benign paroxysmal positional vertigo except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vertigo is mostly transient in BPPV, its duration correlating well with the duration of the positioning nystagmus, which usually resolves within 30 seconds in posterior canal BPPV(pBPPV).

BPPV:

  • It is characterised by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position. There is no hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms. Option C ruled out.
  • Positional testing establishes the diagnosis and helps to differentiate it from positional vertigo of central origin.
  • Disease is caused by a disorder of the posterior semicircular canal, though many patients have a history of head trauma and ear infection.
  • It has been demonstrated that otoconial debris, consisting of crystals of calcium carbonate, is released from the degenerating macula of the utricle and floats freely in the endolymph.
  • When it settles on the cupula of the posterior semicircular canal in a critical head position, it causes displacement of the cupula and vertigo. Option B ruled out.
  • The vertigo is fatigable on assuming the same position repeatedly due to dispersal of the otoconia, but can be induced again after a period of rest. Thus, typical history and Hallpike manoeuvre establish the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • The condition can be treated by performing Epley's manoeuvre. Option D ruled out.
  • The principle of this manoeuvre is to reposition the otoconial debris from the posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presents to the ENT OPD with episodes of vertigo without any hearing loss. The physician first does a diagnostic manoeuvre and later a therapeutic manoeuvre. Identify the manoeuvre given in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above is Dix-Hallpike's Manoeuvre for the diagnosis of BPPV.

BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo):

  • BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo.
  • This disease is more common in females.
  • Otoconia gets displaced and reaches the semicircular canal.
  • The most commonly involved canal is the Posterior SCC

Clinical features:

  • Vertigo for a few seconds on changing head position.
  • Vertigo is associated with nausea and vomiting.
  • There is no hearing loss or Tinnitus in this condition.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnostic test of BPPV- DIX-HALLPICKES MANEUVER. This test shows nystagmus (rotational and geotropic) on putting the patient in the supine position from the sitting position.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of BPPV- EPLEY'S MANEUVER (particle repositioning manoeuvre)- It is the treatment of choice (Option B ruled out).
  • Gutzmann's manoeuvre is a less commonly used repositioning manoeuvre (Option C ruled out).

Steps of EPLEY'S MANEUVER:-

  • Make the patient sit down.
  • Turn the head 45° to the affected side.
  • Make the Patient lie down with the head hanging off the table
  • Rotate the head 90° to the other side.
  • Rotate the body along with the head 90° on the same side.
  • Make the patient sit down.

She has been experiencing this problem for the last 3 days. Which part of the inner ear is the site of origin of the pathology that is likely to be responsible for the given complaint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of BPPV(Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient has been diagnosed with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, with Dix Hallpike test positive for posterior semi-circular canal involvement. She has been suffering from recurrent episodes of BPPV for the last 5 years, which are now not responding to repositioning manoeuvres. The episodes have become more frequent in the last year, which are hampering the daily life of the patient. What is the further treatment modality that can be advised to this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Singular nerve is a branch of the vestibular division of the 8thnerve, which supplies the posterior semicircular canal.
  • Singular neurectomy can be a treatment modality for intractable BPPV.
  • It is the surgical sectioning of the singular nerve (a branch of the vestibular nerve to the posterior canal). Highly effective in stopping vertigo while preserving hearing.
  • The remaining treatment options given are used for the management of Meniere's disease. (Other options ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The fast component of nystagmus is due to the central corrective response.
  • In a vestibular (peripheral) lesion, such as labyrinthitis or vestibular neuritis, the fast phase of nystagmus always beats away from the lesioned side, directed toward the healthy ear. (Option D ruled out)
  • In irritative labyrinthitis (e.g., early inflammation), the increased stimulation causes nystagmus towards the affected ear. (Option B ruled out)
  • In diffuse serous labyrinthitis, there is still some function remaining in the affected ear, leading to irritative-type symptoms, so nystagmus is still towards the affected ear.(Option C ruled out)
  • The fast phase is not a direct consequence of the underlying disease, but rather it's a compensatory mechanism-the brain resets eye position after a slow drift caused by asymmetrical vestibular input.
  • By default, the direction of nystagmus is always taken by the fast component.

questions.text: A person has vertigo which is fatiguable. Causes are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Focal vertigo is seen in peripheral causes of vertigo. Multiple sclerosis causes central vertigo. Fatigable vertigo, where symptoms decrease with repetition (like in Dix–Hallpike), is characteristic of peripheral vestibular disorders-conditions affecting the inner ear or vestibular nerve.

  • Perilymph fistula ( Option A): Causes mechanical disruption in the inner ear, leading to positional, fatigable vertigo.
  • Vestibular neuritis (Option B): An acute inflammation of the vestibular nerve causing spontaneous vertigo, which subsides with time and fatigues with repeated movement.
  • Menière's disease (Option C): A peripheral inner ear disorder marked by episodic vertigo, often positional and fatiguing over time.

questions.text: : All are the proposed treatment modalities for sudden sensorineural hearing loss except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Drugs such as cisplatin, mitomycin-C, 5-fluorouracil, paclitaxel, docetaxel and hydroxyurea have been used in concomitant chemoradiation.
  • They act as radiosensitizers and potentiate the effect of radiation by their additive or synergistic effect, and are not used in SNHL treatment.

Treatment for sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL):

  • Systemic corticosteroids (e.g., oral prednisone or methylprednisolone) as first-line therapy. Option D ruled out.
  • Intratympanic corticosteroids (like dexamethasone or methylprednisolone) are used as salvage or even primary therapy in certain situations. Option A ruled out.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) is offered as an adjunct within the first few weeks, especially when steroids fail or for severe cases. Option C ruled out.
